content.description: Like most routes here, the start is hard and then cruiser up to the anchors.
content.location: Just left of Deal from the Bottom

content.description: A really nice route with two crux moves. Begin with a dino after stick clipping the first bolt (or not, your choice). Then climb through the roof, and throw the second crux off a two finger pocket.
content.location: At the left end of the roof section in the center of the cliff-band.

content.description: Crux at bottom starts with deep two finger pocket, then pulls over bulge.
content.location: Left most route on wall with Sports Book Crack

content.description:
Outside and right of the grotto is a route (not the 5.6) which the first bolt has a hanger and the rest of the route is cold shuts.   

  Clip first bolt while using well chalked sloping and not-so-positive left hand hold.  Look for key pocket below & above 2nd bolt.  Moving past the second bolt is the crux and the route eases once past it.
content.location: The route is just right of Circus Circus 5.6

content.description: Start off with a fairly sequential (seems like everyone does it different) bouldery-style section that gets you to the roof, then pull up and get holds above, then pull like hell. Once you get established above the roof, the climbing eases.
content.location: Just right of the very popular Mickey Goes To Vegas is a good sized roof. This route goes right over this roof.

content.description:
Bolted crack to the left of the main Casino Cliffs area and around the corner from the cave area. The route is a  classic for the area and often a line.  

  Right facing dihedral - bolted crack.  Rumor has it a hold broke off around the second clip, I didn't notice any real difference in the route or the grade.
content.protection:
6 bolts to jumbo sized welded shuts.   

  One of the original anchors is still above replacements.  The second has a bolt shaft but no shut.  This is a good example on why it is important to hang draws while top roping.  Grit and friction wore out this and many other anchors in the area.
content.location: Around the corner to the left of the grotto area by 4 routes.

content.description: Pumpy route with many pockets.  Try and not burn out before making the anchor.
content.location:
There is a small section of climbs located on the far left side of Casino Cliffs.  These routes can be accessed from the main trail and heading far left while following the base or by taking the left fork when cutting over to Casino Wall when coming from the Main Wall or Cracker Jack.   

  Driectly right of Edge your bets.  Watch for the trail to gain a bit of elevation.  The base is at that point of the trail

content.description: Challenging start
content.location: To the left of Fist Full of Dollars

content.description: This route is very fun once you're about to the third bolt, before that it has an insanely thin section that's pretty tough.  Guidebook (route # 25) says 5.10d, but we both thought this one is opposite of most Jack's routes, closer to 5.11a.  Once past the crux, the moves are very fluid and fun.  Good route.
content.protection: 5 bolts will get you to the fixed anchors and your rappel.
content.location: This route is five feet right of Dealers Choice and about 15-20 feet left of where the trail meets the Casino cliffs wall.

content.description: Start with a sequence of 4 underclings and bad feet to gain a decent rest.  Pull another thin undercling and get the left-hand sloper/pinch just over the small roof.  Deadpoint to sidepull and bump or just go straight to the horizontal - either way this feels like the crux.  Dyno (or strenuous cross) to the LEFT of the last draw.  This makes for three difficult sections in a short route for an overall good climb!  Feels a tad easier than Hold or Fold to the right at 12b
content.location: not too far left of Mikey (look for obvious series of underclings)

content.description:
Hard start - really makes you think!   

  For those of you who want to climb at Jacks, it would be wise for you to invest in the Jacks Canyon guide that Deidre Burton put together.  You can visitjackscanyon.com to order it.  It is well worth the cost, because if you can't locate one route in an area at Jacks - then me telling you that a route is "to the left" or "to the right" of another route is not going to help you.  Deidre put out a quality guidebook, and I hope it helps you find your way in the canyon!
Nice warmup or first lead.  Unlike Circus Circus down the wall to the left, this is an actual 5.6 that beginning leaders will be comfortable on.  Trickier start to easy big ledges above.
content.location: Climbs buttress where the wall juts out to the right of the main trail from the parking lot.  Right of the ramp.  Between harder climbs, so the 5.6 holds should be obvious.

content.description: Bouldery start just left of large roof.  If you hit sports book you've gone too far by two routes.
content.location: Around the corner from the grotto.  This route is just left of a large roof.

content.description: Follow the trail down into the canyon, and you'll notice two large boulders about 30 yards to the right of the main landing area. This climb starts on the left side of the wall, on and up the arete. Great route, don't forget to use the arete
Short but steep route on the far left end of Casino Cliffs.  The route works you through 3 roofs before gaining the anchors.
content.location:
There is a small section of climbs located on the far left side of Casino Cliffs.  These routes can be accessed from the main trail and heading far left while following the base or by taking the left fork when cutting over to Casino Wall when coming from the Main Wall or Cracker Jack.   

  Mustang Ranch is the very first route on the far left.  It is a loaner - no other routes directly left or right of it.

content.description: I think this could be the best moderate on Casino cliffs and a great fun route.  The holds and movement are really fun with a great roof move added for spice.  Nothing is bad about this route unless you don't do it, have fun!
content.protection: 6 bolts will get you up this beauty to the fixed anchors and your rappel.  Well protected.
content.location: This route you can not miss, it is directly in front of you where the main trail meets the Casino cliffs wall.  Obvious large holds on crack down low is Mickeys!!!

content.description: High first bolt. Stick climb isn’t a bad idea if this is near your limit. Not the easiest 10a at Casino Cliffs.
content.location: Between B.A.M. and Ante Up.

content.description: Sequential moves on small pockets get you to the first ledge. Crux to a clipping hold for the second bolt. More sharp pockets and ledges to finish up.
content.location: In between “Texas Holdem” and “Lost Wages,” up the left side of the bulge.

content.description: The Crux comes immediately on this awesome route, pulling over a black bulge with a side pull and pockets with minimal feet. If you're shorter than 5'10" this may feel on the harder side of 12d for you.Lost Wages is an awesome bolted boulder problem, after the crux you get a great rest at a horizontal crack and then crank hard through 5.11 to the top.
content.location: One route left of Sports Book the classic 5.10a crack/layback.

content.description: I kept the 10a rating from the Jacks guidebook. The 10 move is down low at the start.  The rest of the route is much easier after the first 15 feet.
content.location: Immediately to the right of One Armed Bandit.

content.description: positive but thin pockets and edges off the ground, to and easier finish (with one strange mantle at a horizontal.
content.location: to the left of wild card ( the furthest left of the 12's on the steep section of the wall)

content.description: Fun 5.8 climbing. Start by climbing up to a ledge before getting to the 5.8 climbing.
content.location: Located immedietly to the left of (I Am) Gumby and to the right of Fist Full O' Dollars

content.description: Thin and technical, the crux is in the obvious location after clipping the second bolt.
content.location: At the right end of the roof section in the central area of the cliff-band.

content.description:
This powerful line is like most routes on this wall, a powerful bouldery start leads to a rest, then some pulls over the small roofs. 

  Start on some angled right facing sidepulls to a big move to a pocket out left.  Continue through a set of pockets into the crux.  Negotiate how to get through the bad crimps and snag a nice rest below the roof.  From here continue up on easier ground with one tricky move between you and the chains.
content.protection: 6 bolts to Anchors.  Worked well to put long draws on the third and sixth bolts.
content.location: Starts to the right of "Read em and Weep" and left of "High Roller"  Second climb left of the bolted crack dihedral that is "Dealer's Choice".

content.description: Smooth holds through a white-ish rock face lead to big stair-like climbing up to a nice ledge to clip the anchors. This is another nice first lead route at Jacks.
content.protection: 4 or 5 bolts to cold shuts anchor.
content.location: This route is immediately left of the popular 5.6 route "Progressive Slots."  It starts in an obvious white streak of rock to a good ledge and on to many more good ledges.

content.description: Book says, "You can bet on desperate moves at the top"
content.location: # 6 in '97 Burton/Steagall guide book. Older bolts on a face left of Texas Holdem and Lucky Streak.

content.description: Recommended well protected sport route up the arete!  First bolt is about 15 feet up but very easy to get to.  Crux is between third and fourth bolt and features some tricky sidepulling and some delicate footwork for a move or two.  Good overall route!!
content.protection: 4 Bolts will get you to the fixed anchors on the ledge above for your rappel.
content.location: The trail that meets the Casino cliffs will put you right in front of the route "Mickey Goes to Vegas", take a right turn and its the first left facing arete you'll come to about 100 feet away.  Look for an easy corner feature to take you to the first bolt above a small ledge about 15 feet up.  This is route # 29 in the guidebook.

content.description: Bouldery start up an obvious straight line using many positive pockets.  Not as many features as it's neighboring route but seems about the same in difficulty.
content.location:
There is a small section of climbs located on the far left side of Casino Cliffs.  These routes can be accessed from the main trail and heading far left while following the base or by taking the left fork when cutting over to Casino Wall when coming from the Main Wall or Cracker Jack.   

  "Edge Your Bets" is on a wall with many pockets and the face shares with "Slots O Fun" to the right.  As a landmark, while walking the trail (either direction) you are taken up a small hill before dropping back down.  The route is found at that point of the trail.

content.description: The crux of this route just like Circus Circus next to it is the layback awkward start.  Once you bust onto the face, the holds are huge and the route is very enjoyable till the anchors.
content.protection: 4 Bolts help you get to the nice fixed anchors on top and your rappel down.
content.location: This route is at Casino cliffs; once you reach the Casino wall, take a left a good 100 yards and look for a right facing corner with two moderate looking routes on it and you'll be set.

content.description: The guidebook doesn't give this a recommendation, but I thought it was fun.  Some of the rock in the chimney to the right is questionable, but the exposure and groundfall potential make for a pretty exciting sport route.  Good variety of moves, pretty sustained.  Climbs cool rock formation, but be careful getting to the bolt above it, it's a long way to the ground and the first bolt probably won't keep you from cratering.
content.location: On far left Casino Cliffs.  Look for a black-stained dihedral (Bet on Black, 5.9).  Double or Nothin' goes up the strange-looking tower/chimney thing to the left.

content.description: Another Jacks Canyon bolted crack but fun nonetheless!  Crux is probably between the first and second bolt, be a bit careful here as you might not want to fall here?  Sustained good route though with some helpful rests along the way.  Good quality route, have at it!  PS:  Guidebook says 5.10c but I think it goes closer to 10a/b IMHO, you choose?
content.protection: 6 Bolts and some fixed anchors at the top just waiting for you.
content.location: On the trail to Casino cliffs, this climb is about 20 feet to the left from where the trail meets the wall in a small right facing corner/crack with bolts, can't miss it!

content.description: Hard start on sharp, sequential monos to much easier climbing after the 2nd bolt.
content.location: Towards the right end of Casino Cliffs.

climbs.name: Daddy (hearts) Longlegs
climbs.fa: L. Reinmuth, P. Zurcher, J. Kendall, P. Anderson

content.description:
Just right of Gamblin Fever. Scramble up to ledge to clip first bolt. Good warm-up or first lead. 

  For whatever reason MP dislikes emoticons!  The name of the route is "Daddy ♥'s Longlegs.
content.protection: 4 bolts to anchors with quick links.

content.description: Just right of Sports Book.  Opening moves are tough as you use side pulls and reach high to an undercling.  The crux is likely the first few bolts but the fun doesn't end 'til you clip the anchors!
content.location: Directly right of "Sports Book".  The start and finish of these two routes are kinda close quarters.  If someone is on Sports Book, it would be best to wait it out until finished.

content.description: Rated as a 5.6, but I don't think a 5.6 leader would be happy on the crux lower portion.  The area around the first and second bolts will be exciting if you think you're on a 5.6.  Considerably harder than Progressive Slot (5.6) down the wall.
content.location: In the corner to the right of a big alcove.  A small, adorable, backpack-eating mouse lives in a notch at the bottom of the climb.  Hide your Clif Bars.

content.description: Not very pleasant, hard balancey route with an obvious crux getting to the second bolt.   beta in my comment if you're looking for it.
content.location: This is the route on the arete just beside Easy Money.

content.description: Decent but fairly short route that follows a crack and lieback flake, although I remember there being quite a few face holds as well. Crux is near the top where the feet get a bit tricky. The guide calls this 10b, but it seems much easier, even by Jacks standards.
content.location: Starting at the far right end of Casino Cliffs, this is 4th route to the left.

content.description: Crux is on the bulge.
content.location: Immediately left of One Armed Bandit.  Climb left of the chimney on the rounded arete.

content.description: This is the last route on the right for this mini Casino Cliffs area.  A little bit taller than it's neighbors to the left, this route is on a black slabby face right of dihedral.
content.location:
There is a small section of climbs located on the far left side of Casino Cliffs.  These routes can be accessed from the main trail and heading far left while following the base or by taking the left fork when cutting over to Casino Wall when coming from the Main Wall or Cracker Jack.   

  Last route on the far right of this area.  There is several hundred feet before you reach the next set of routes starting with "Gamblin' Fever"

content.description: Thin and reachy in places.
content.location: Line right of Black Jack Crack

content.description: Decent route but fairly stout (thin) for a 5.8 like the guidebook suggests.  The route is very short so I would only recommend if already in the area working some of the 5.10 routes on the same wall.
content.protection: 3 Bolts will get you to the fixed anchors and your rappel
content.location: This is the furthest route on the right side of the Casino cliffs and is up a small dirt ramp to get to the base of the route.  Many 5.10 routes are just left of this short route.

content.description:
Starting on dark slick rock use crimpy holds as you reach right to a well chalked flake.  The crack behind the flake gets slightly larger and more positive with every inch.  Footwork is key.   

  Route eases considerably after the second clip.
content.location: Tucked away in grotto on the wall to the right.

content.description: This route can be climbed without using any of the holds on its neighbors, but the crux sequence is devious. Worth doing; it’s fun to solve the puzzle.
content.location: Between Roll the Dice and Mickey Goes to Vegas. Shares anchor with Roll the Dice.

content.description: Casino cliffs is the first major climbing area at Jacks Canyon you'll come to and is immediately across the canyon from the bottom of the access trail from the campsites.  With morning sun and afternoon shade you can always pick the right season here.  Grades of all abilities and typically great solid rock and well protected routes makes this a great area for climbers wanting variety but expect a social gathering.  Fairly well protected from the common winds as a bonus!!  Have Fun
